The Rise of Black Churches in North America
Period: !!smallcaps|ad!! 1773–1969
Description: The Black Church in North America developed as a distinct expression of Christianity within the context of slavery, the Jim Crow era, and the Civil Rights Movement.
Summary: The Black Church in North America emerged out of the encounter of the Christian faith and white supremacy.
It developed separately from the distinct, ancient Christian churches in Africa.

In diaspora because of the Atlantic slave trade, Africans in the United States and their descendants contextualized Christianity to express their dignity and devotion within the context of slavery, Jim Crow, and the Civil Rights Movement.
Key Developments
Enslaved converts to Christianity expressed their faith in spite of the restrictions of slaveholders, leading to unique worship traditions (late 1700s–mid-1800s).
Northern, free Blacks established many national denominations in the face of white exclusion (early 1800s).
Southern, white slaveholders resisted the independent churches of Black Americans, fearing gospel preaching and worship would lead to emancipation (first half of the 1800s.
After emancipation, Black Americans were generally expelled from white congregations (second half of the 1800s.

Emancipation and the Great Migration led to the establishment of additional Black denominations, with theological diversity ranging from mainline denominations to independent, fundamentalist denominations (1863–1970).
The experience of Jim Crow forced African American religious leaders to respond in ways which ultimately shaped the role and cultural idea of the Black pastor as civic leader (c. 1877–c. 1950).
The Black Church’s clergy were integral to the organization and success of the Civil Rights Movement as a non-violent, liturgical protest movement (1954-1968).
Black liberation theology developed (1969).
The post-Civil Rights Era has provoked divergence and synthesis in various Black American traditions (1968–2022).
Key People

George Liele (1750-1820): Black American Baptist pastor and missionary; founder of First Bryan Baptist Church and First African Baptist Church in Savannah, Georgia, two of the earliest Black churches in North America; he became missionary to Jamaica and was the first North American missionary.

Richard Allen (1760-1831): Black American bishop and founder of the African Methodist Episcopal Church (AME); he was an abolitionist with the Free African Society; pastored Mother Bethel AME Church, one of the oldest Black churches in America; author of The Life, Experience, and Gospel Labours of the Rt. Rev. Richard Allen.

Daniel Alexander Payne (February 24, 1811–November 2, 1893): Black American bishop in African Methodist Episcopal Church (AME), educator, college administrator, and author; he founded Wilberforce College in Ohio to train Black clergy and was the first African American college president.

Reverdy C. Ransom (January 4, 1861–April 22, 1959): Black American bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church (AME); Christian socialist and civil rights activist; he was co-founder of Niagara Movement, which proceeded the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).

William Joseph Seymour (1870–1922): Black American Holiness preacher and Pentecostal revivalist; leader of the Azusa Street Revival; pastor of the Apostolic Faith Gospel Mission in Los Angeles; he founded The Apostolic Faith newspaper.

Nannie Helen Burroughs (May 2, 1879–May 20, 1961): Black American Baptist educator, orator, and social activist; she organized Black churches to respond to social issues through auxiliary units, including the Women's Convention Auxiliary to the NBC; she delivered the address “How the Sisters Are Hindered from Helping” at the 1900 National Baptist Convention; established the National Training School for Women and Girls, which was renamed the Nannie Helen Burroughs School after her death.

Howard Thurman (1899-1981): Black American theologian and civil rights activist; he studied at Morehouse College; author of the influential work Jesus and the Disinherited; he co-founded the first intentionally integrated church in North America, Church for the Fellowship of All Peoples in San Francisco.

Mahalia Jackson (1911-1972): Black gospel singer and three-time Grammy winner; she influenced the genre of gospel blues in Black congregational worship; one of largest financial supporters of the Civil Rights Movement.

Martin Luther King Jr. (January 15, 1929–April 4, 1968): Black American Baptist minister and civil rights activist; leader of the Civil Rights Movement in the United States; he studied at Morehouse College; he helped pass the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965; author of "Letter from Birmingham Jail"; he was assassinated in Memphis in 1968.
James Hal Cone (August 5, 1938–April 28, 2018): Black American Methodist (AME) theologian; he developed Black theology and Black liberation theology; author of Black Theology and Black Power.
Key Events
1700s: Slave trade begins in the British Empire.
1773: George Liele founds the first Black church in North America.
1777: First African Baptist Church of Savannah is founded.
1784: Methodist Episcopal Church is founded.
1816: Richard Allen is appointed bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Church.
1831: Nat Turner’s Rebellion takes place in Southampton County, Virginia.
1856: Wilberforce College is founded.
January 1, 1863: Abraham Lincoln gives the Emancipation Proclamation declaring enslaved African Americans in the Confederate States free.
1865: Black churches form in North America.
1867: Morehouse College is founded.
1867: National Holiness Association is founded; Vineland, NJ camp meeting focuses on the doctrine of holiness.
1895: National Baptist Convention is formed.
c. 1877–c. 1950: Jim Crow era in the United States.
1900: National Baptist Convention is held in Richmond, Virginia.
1905: Niagara Movement is organized by W. E. B. Du Bois.
1906: Azusa Street Revival holds integrated meetings.
1916–1970: Black Americans move out of the southern United States in the Great Migration.
1954–1968: Civil Rights Movement takes place in the United States.
1968: Martin Luther King Jr. is assassinated.
1969: Black Theology and Black Power by James H. Cone is published.
Key Places
Morehouse College is an historically Black men's liberal arts college in Atlanta, Georgia; Martin Luther King Jr. and Howard Thurman studied here.
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, was where the African Methodist Episcopal Church was founded.
Savanna, Georgia, was where two of the earliest Black churches in America, First Bryan Baptist Church and First African Baptist Church, were founded.
Wilberforce College is an historically Black private college in Ohio; it was founded by Daniel Alexander Payne and is associated with the African Methodist Episcopal Church (AME).
Key Concepts
African Methodist Episcopal Church was established after Black Americans faced discrimination within Methodist churches.
Black churches were established by Black Americans beginning in the seventeenth century as Black Christians in North America experienced discrimination in predominantly white churches.
Church of God in Christ is a Holiness-Pentecostal denomination with a predominantly Black membership; it was founded by Charles H Mason in 1897.
Key Documents
Addresses

“How the Sisters Are Hindered from Helping” (Nannie Helen Burroughs, September 13, 1900): delivered at the 1900 National Baptist Convention in Richmond, Virginia; addresses the injustices women faced within Baptist churches in North America and advocates for the participation of women in the mission of the church.
Autobiographies

The Life, Experience, and Gospel Labours of the Rt. Rev. Richard Allen (Richard Allen, 1833): recounts events from Allen's life, including his time as an enslaved person before purchasing his freedom; includes an address to slaveholders and those who approved of the practice, as well as an address to people of color, both those who had found freedom and those who were still enslaved.
Treatises

Jesus and the Disinherited (Howard Thurman, 1949): an important work to the Civil Rights Movement; addresses oppression and nonviolence and calls those who are oppressed to reject fear, deception, and hate.

Black Theology and Black Power (James Hal Cone, 1969): addresses the relationship between Black and white people in America; develops a Black theology that attempts to reconcile Black power, which Cone describes as "black freedom, black self-determination, wherein black people no longer view themselves as without human dignity,"[^1] with Christianity.

“How the Sisters Are Hindered from Helping” (Nannie Helen Burroughs, September 13, 1900): delivered at the 1900 National Baptist Convention in Richmond, Virginia; addresses the injustices women faced within Baptist churches in North America and advocates for the participation of women in the mission of the church.
